subject: Re: [Read_Alphabet] Pronounciation of .Ah and .Awe
msgSnippet: While Kingsley Read did not make it clear in the manual whether he wanted a standardised representation or dialectic, In practice - as in his correspondence
messageBody:
While Kingsley Read did not make it clear in the manual whether he
wanted a standardised representation or dialectic, In practice - as in
his correspondence worldwide - he encouraged everyone to spell
according to their way of speaking. Don't however recall h actually
stating this prefer ce in writing though. I will have to go over the
few letters he wrote to me individually (most of our correspondence
was round robin). If I can find anything pertinent I will publish it
to the list.

Regards

Moira

On Sunday, August 30, 2009, John Cowan <cowan@...> wrote:
>
>
>
>
>
>
>
>
>
>
>
>
>
>
>
>
>
>
> hombredepescado scripsit:
>
>>
>> Firstly, I understand that with the British pronunciation of .Ah
>> and .Awe, there would be a considerable difference. However, in
>> the common North American accent, I don't think we pronounce these
>> differently -- do we?
>
> About half of North Americans make the distinction. Very roughly,
> Eastern and Southern accents do, and Canadian and Western accents don't.
> All of the other varieties of English make the distinction.
>
>> If yes, then how so?
>
> Most people who don't make the distinction use only the sound of Ah.
> However, they *do* make the sound of Awe when saying "Awwwwwwww!!!!", the
> expression of (mock-)sympathy; we do not mix this up with "Ahhhhhh!",
> the sound of satisfaction or relief. For most people who make the
> distinction, the word "awe" is just a shorter form of this expression.
> When traditional orthography writes "au" or "aw", this generally
> represents Awe.
>
> Similarly, Americans, except those from Eastern New England, have trouble
> knowing when to write the Ox sound, since most of us use Ah instead.
> Traditional spelling is likewise fairly reliable here: if we write "o"
> or "wa" it's Ox, if we write "a" otherwise it's Ah.
>
>> Secondly, what didn't seem clear to me from Read's manual was whether
>> you should write according to your own pronunciation, or whether there
>> was some 'master' pronunciation to which you write phonetically.
>
> Read never made that clear. He obviously had an ideal accent in mind,
> which was basically RP, but with "r" where the rhotic accents have it.
> This list has been working on an "international spelling" that will
> preserve most of the distinctions made by different accents of English,
> at the expense of not being quite the same as anyone's actual accent.
>
> For example, RP-speakers and Australians will have to distinguish in
> writing between Ah and Start, whereas most North Americans will have to
> distinguish in writing between Ah and Ox, as I mentioned above. This is
> like what Spanish does in distinguishing in writing between the letters
> "s" and "z", which the great majority of all Spanish-speakers pronounce
> the same, but which are pronounced differently in certain parts of Spain,
> historically including the capital, the source of the prestige accent
> in Spain. (English as a whole has no prestige accent.)
>
> --
> Don't be so humble. You're not that great. John Cowan
> --Golda Meir cowan@... <cowan%40ccil.org>
